Paragraphs: FROM_THE_PRESIDENT,

As I had announced in the December 2016 issue
A of The CN Journal, this is an election year for

the RCNA. This issue of the Journal contains
important election information, please take the time to
review this information.

I would like to thank our long-time member Paul Petch,
who volunteered as Nominations Committee Chairperson,
for his effort and diligence in collecting the nominations he
received. His efforts are seen throughout the pages of this
issue of the Journal.

Please note that legislated changes to our By-Laws in
July, 2014, required us to make changes to our previous
election procedures.

If you look at the ballot and covering letter, included as
inserts with this issue, you will notice that you have the
opportunity to cast your vote for every director position,
including those for which there is only one candidate
standing for election.

Additionally, you will also notice that there is a section
at the end of the ballot for you to include your name
and signature. This information is required in order for
your ballot to be valid and to allow you to revoke and re-
register your vote during the Annual General Meeting.
The AGM will be held in Boucherville, Quebec, at 10:30
a.m. Saturday July 22nd in the Iles Perc es B room of the
Hotel Mortagne and Convention Centre. Please be aware
that your vote will be kept completely confidential. NO
information about your vote is made available to anyone,
other than the Election Officers. Members who serve in
this position are obligated to keep all voting information
confidential. Refer to the cover letter for more detailed
explanations regarding these changes.

Please take the time to review the election information
contained in this issue and mail in your vote early. To
ensure that your vote is counted your ballot must be
received no later than Thursday, June 22, 2017. Remember
to allow plenty of time for Canada Post to get your ballot
choices to the Elections Committee in Boucherville.

Even if you intend to be at the meeting, it is important
that you complete this ballot to register your vote at
the meeting. I truly hope that you read the information
available to you and above all get your ballot in! This is
your opportunity to help the Association move forward.

In closing I want to remind you that our next executive
meeting will be held on Sunday, July, 23, during our
Annual Convention in Boucherville, Quebec. All members
are invited to attend as observers.

2017 CONVENTION_MEDAL MEDAILLE_DU_CONGRES

he 2017 official Convention Medal presents a
| portrait of Louis-Hippolyte Lafontaine and the
house where he grew up in Boucherville,
host city of the Convention. Two elements
intimately linked with the history of
Boucherville, Quebec, and Canada.
Louis-Hippolyte Lafontaine was
born in Boucherville, Lower-
Canada, October 4, 1807 (210
years ago). He was the third
son of Antoine M nard, dit
La Fontaine, carpenter, and
Marie-Josephte Fontaine, dit
Bienvenue. Louis-Hippolyte was
admitted to the bar in 1828. In
1830, he became active in politics,
being elected Deputy for Terrebonne
in the House of Assembly of Lower
Canada. He married Ad le Bertholot on
July 9, 1831.
In his political life Lafontaine proved
to be a man of compromise during the
tormented period of the rebellion of
1837 in Lower Canada.
He was appointed Prime Minister of
Canada East between 1842 and 1843
and from 1848 to 1851, making him the
first democratically elected head of a
government anywhere in the colonies
of world empires.
Appointed at the age of 34, Lafontaine
was the youngest French-Canadian
prime minister in history. He is known
to have made the first speech in French
in Parliament despite the adoption of
the Act of Union, which prohibited its
use. This civil disobedience was his first
gesture as prime minister in 1842.
Lafontaine, tired and sick, retired
on September 26, 1851. He was later
appointed Chief Justice of the Court of
Queen s Bench in 1853 and was made
baronet by Queen Victoria in 1854. He died in Montreal on
February 26, 1864.
The mintages of the 2017 RCNA medal are as follows:
Bronze   190; Silver   55.
Each pre-registration kit includes a bronze medal, and
extra bronze medals are available for $20.00 each.
The cost of the silver medal is $60.00.

2017 RCNA ELECTION INFORMATION
Candidate for President / Candidat a la pr sidence
Henry Nienhuis, FRCNA, FCNRS, FONA

Throughout his career, Henry Nienhuis,
a software professional who graduated
from the University of Toronto
specializing in Computer Science, has
led a number of high tech development
teams in producing innovative
technologies.
Henry has been collecting Canadian,
British and Dutch coins, tokens and
medals for over 45 years. After a hiatus
from the hobby to attend University and

raise a family, he returned to organized
numismatics in 2000 serving the hobby at local,
provincial and national levels. For a number of years
he served the RCNA as Education Chairman, managing
the annual symposium, and as Associate Editor of The
Canadian Numismatic Journal. He has contributed to
the growth and direction of the RCNA when called
upon as a member of Strategic Planning initiatives. In
addition, he has served as Director of the Association
and is the current President. In 2014, he served as
Co-chair of the Annual Convention. Most recently, as
the editor of The CN Journal he successfully led the
publication s move to the larger format.

He is a member of the executive of a number of
clubs- ONA, NYCC, TCC, EMCSCC and CEVNA
and has also served as their Webmaster. He is a board
member of the non-profit Canadian Association for
Numismatic Education and J. Douglas Ferguson
Historical Research Foundation.

He is a fellow of the Canadian Numismatic
Research Society, the RCNA and the ONA. In 2015,
he was honoured with the ONA Award of Merit, the
highest award bestowed by that Association, and in
2017, he received the Bruce H. Raszmann Award.

Henry has published in The CN Journal, Canadian
Coin News, and the Ontario Numismatist. A three
times winner of the Jean Bullen Award, he has spoken
at numismatic clubs, community shows, and to
Association Conventions.

Tout au long de sa carri re, Henry
Nienhuis, un professionnel dans les
logiciels qui a obtenu son dipl me de
l'Universit  de Toronto en sp cialisation
informatique, a dirig  plusieurs  quipes
de d veloppement de haute technologie
dans la production de technologies
d  innovations.

Henry collectionne des pi ces
canadiennes, britanniques et
n erlandaises, des jetons et des m dailles
depuis plus de 45 ans. Apr s une pause

de son passe-temps pour ces  tudes   l'universit  et  lever sa
famille, il est retourn    la numismatique en 2000, et servie
la communaut  numismatique aux niveaux local, provincial
et national. Pendant plusieurs ann es, il a servi   l'ARNC en
tant que pr sident du volet  ducation, la gestion du symposium
annuel, et en tant que r dacteur en chef adjoint du journal
canadien de numismatique. Il a contribu    la croissance et la
direction de l ARNC lorsqu'il fut demand  d tre membre des
initiatives de planification strat gique. De plus, il a servi en
tant que directeur de l'association et est pr sentement pr sident.
En 2014, il a servi en tant que co-pr sident de la convention
annuelle. Plus r cemment, en tant que r dacteur en chef du
journal canadien de numismatique, il a dirig  avec succ s la

Yvon Marquis began collecting in the
1960s at the age of 12. In 1976, he joined
his first club, La Soci t  Numismatique

Numismatic Association. In April 1979,
he founded le Club de Numismates du

Yvon attended his first CNA

regional levels; in 1986 he received the Royal
Canadian Mint Award for Numismatic Education, in

he received the Guy Potter Literary award and in
1997, the Jerry Remick Literary Award.

For over 35 years Yvon has made significant
contributions to the hobby as a member of a number of
committees. He participated with the Royal Canadian

the people he has met over the years; some of them are
now his very good friends.

William O'Brien: Candidate for Director representing Ontario - South-Central / Candidat au poste de
Directeur repr sentant de Ontario - Sud-Centre
Like most numismatists my quest began at a very young
age. I remember examining each coin from my parents
change with the hope of finding a shinny old 1-cent piece
or a silver King George coin. My interests soon grew
exponentially as I discovered world coins through those I
received from my parents and relatives. I was hooked for

life and the bug never left, only went dormant.
After obtaining a BBA from the University of Prince Edward
Island, marrying a local girl and producing a beautiful daughter
many busy years ensued with building up a successful small
company. In 2000 my collecting interests were rekindled when life
became more stable and I resumed where I left off some twenty-
five years previous. It quickly expanded to include tokens and
other numismatic items especially related to my family s history. A
customer explained that the best way to expand my knowledge was
to join a coin club and directed me to a nearby church basement

where the EMCCC met. This friendship and fellowship
has lasted some fifteen years. I still attend these club
meetings along with those of the NYCC, for which I am
honoured to be the president for a third term.
My involvement locally has encouraged me to
join the larger organizations which include the ONA,
CPMS, CATC, ANA and the RCNA for which I am
currently an area director. The NYCC was the host club for the
2014 RCNA annual convention and as club President I was proud
to host my fellow numismatists. The ability to share knowledge
and passion within these organizations is what drives me to
become more actively involved. In the future I see myself always
striving not only to gain knowledge relevant to my collection, but
to encourage new collectors to develop their passions and to share
in the camaraderie, which I believe is just as important as finding
the missing piece for a collection.

Scott Douglas: Candidate for Director representing North and East Ontario / Candidat au poste de
Directeur repr sentant de Ontario - Nord et Est
Scott E. Douglas first became interested in collecting

coins at the age of 6 when the principal of his school
(appropriately named Mr. Nichol) called him down to

his office and upon wishing Scott a  Happy Birthday 
presented him with a newly minted 1958 5 centavos
coin of Peru. Naturally the infamous Whitman boards
were next and interest grew from there. Sometime
around 1992 Canadian tokens and medals caught

Scott s interest and he hasn t looked back since. Scott is a
member of several coin clubs and a Life member of the RCNA.
In 1994 he became a Knight of St. Eligius the Patron Saint of
numismatists.

Scott is a charter member of the South Wellington Coin
Society serving as the Society s first President from 1997 to
2000 and currently is the treasurer and President (2016) as
the club enters its 20th year. Scott also serves on the Board
of Directors and is the SWCS Archivist and Club Historian.
He is a past President, Vice-President and a member of the
Board of Directors of the Buffalo Numismatic Association
helping turn this club around from 6 members in 1997 to over
200 members by 2006. Scott is currently the club Historian for
the BNA. He is also past Archivist for the Toronto Coin Club
and is currently Vice-President of the Canadian Association of
Token Collectors. In 2006 Scott became the Canadian Director
for Encased Collectors International an internet based club

dedicated to collecting encased coins. Scott has given
presentations in the past during the RCNA annual
one-day course at Humber College in Toronto and
was one of the speakers at the Educational Forum
during the 2004, 2008 and 2011 RCNA conventions.
Scott is a Fellow and immediate past President
of the Canadian Numismatic Research Society and
has written numerous articles on numismatics that
have been published in various club journals and newsletters.
He has also written a brief History of the Buffalo Numismatic
Association on the occasion of the club s 75th Anniversary, and
has privately published a book on the life of W.R. McColl in
collaboration with Len Buth. In 2005 the London Numismatic
Association published Scott s fifty-eight page booklet entitled
Early Canadian Numismatists and Their Tokens for which the
Canadian Numismatic Research Society awarded him the Fred
Bowman literary award.

Scott has published the story of Jeremiah Gibbs one of
Canada s most influential numismatists and writes the  Did
You Know  column for the SWCS monthly newsletter. Scott
collaborated with Chris Faulkner on the book of The Pritchard
and Andrews Company of Ottawa, Ontario and had the honour
of being recognized once again with the Fred Bowman Literary
Award for 2008 and the Lloyd Smith literary award given by the
London Numismatic Society for the same work.

PORTRAITS OF THE FAMOUS
BY. MEDALLISTS.OF_ RENOWN
BY BARRIE RENWICK
FRCNA, FCNRS, #5754,
#4 Marshal Foch by Oscar Nemon

The Foch medal by Oscar Nemon expresses the
| gratitude of the Comit  Belge for Foch, as Allied
Commander-in-Chief, forcing the enemy to seek
armistice in 1918, ending the war. The medal s
obverse, in Nemon s high-relief Cubist-
style, portrays a stalwart G n ralissime
buttressed by the massive incuse
legend FOCH. Nemon designed
the piece without a rim, which
would be distracting. Around its
bland reverse is the committee s
tribute, and diagonally across,
a facsimile of Foch s signature
on the armistice. The medal is
bronze, 70 mm in diameter, with
Nemon s monogram and the date,
1930, at the obverse bottom. Comit
Belge, was an empowered coalition of
Belgium s political entities, directing the
country s wartime activities and supporting
the Allies.
Ferdinand Foch, born 1851 a son of a
civil servant in regional France, chose
military service as his career. He
joined the army at age nineteen.
In time, through diligence and
study he rose in rank, which
added responsibilities. By the
late nineteenth century he was
a Lieutenant-Colonel, and in the
early twentieth, a Brigade General.
Foch was a Corps Commander
when war erupted in 1914. In its
early years he led troops and planned
battle strategies. As war in the European
theatre dragged on there were
successes, setbacks and obstinate
stalemates, but always dreadful
carnage. Allied command altered
strategies and rotated field commanders hoping to gain
advantage, but attrition persisted. The arrival of US
forces bolstered those of the Allied nations making their

victory look attainable. To succeed, a central command
of forces was essential, and in early 1918 Foch was
appointed Supreme Commander of the Allied Armies.
At Compi gne, Foch imposed the Allies  armistice
that Erzberger accepted on behalf of the
Central Powers. After, Foch was active
in the 1919 Paris Peace Conference
that settled affairs, but he remained
skeptical about the strength of its
upshot, the Treaty of Versailles. In
1921 he toured the United States;
there he attended civic functions,
received honours and got public
acclaim. Ferdinand Foch, a hero
to the French, died in 1929.
Oscar Nemon born 1906 in
Osijek, in today s Croatia, showed
an early artistic ability as a teen. While
still a student, he exhibited his art and
gained public acclaim. Nemon began formal
art studies in Vienna and continued later in
Brussels at its Royal Academy. In 1924
when visiting the World Fair in Paris,
a Russian display of Cubist-style art
fascinated him. He adopted this style
for a time as several of his medals
and sculptures affirm. His first
one-man show was in Brussels in
1932. In the late 1930s Nemon,
a Hebrew, sensed a looming
danger from the changing political
atmosphere. Wary of his safety, he
left the continent in 1938 to settle near
Oxford in England. In time, he married
there, took citizenship and developed
his career as a sculptor. In the
1950s, Nemon sculpted Winston
Churchill. They became fast
friends. After Churchill s passing,
Nemon was selected to prepare Churchill s image for
Britain s 1965 commemorative crown. Oscar Nemon died
in 1985 aged 79.
CANADIAN. SPICE
BY ROGER C. PAULEN
1908 Large Cent, Large over Small Obverse Legend
I n 1908, production of Canadian decimal

coinage shifted from the Royal
Mint, London, and the Heaton

Mint, Birmingham, to the Royal
Mint Branch, Ottawa. Generally,
production varieties and variances
in coins struck diminished
considerably relative to the earlier
Provincial and Canadian large
cent series. Thus, the majority of
die studies and research efforts
are almost all limited to the
Victorian strikes.

The coin featured this month is
a wonderful doubled die, which has
gone unreported by previous generations
of collectors. It is the 1908 large cent with
a repunched obverse legend (Figure 1). Despite
Jack Griffin s extensive research on Canadian
large cents, there is no mention of this
variety in his Monograph #1 (Griffin,
2010) or Monograph #3 (Griffin,
2006). None of the Hans Zoell
variety publications (from 1961 to
1970) document this die variety.

Almost the entire obverse
legend has its elements
repunched, but this is especially
noticeable from DEI (at 11
o clock) to IMPERATOR
(5 o clock). However, close
examination of the doubled elements
shows that this is not just a doubled die
from the preparation of the matrix
or master dies. The doubling is
more than just the splitting of serifs,
like those seen on other doubled
(or even tripled) dies (Ash, 2011).
The doubling appears mainly on the lower portions of
each obverse legend letter, as though a larger font was
repunched over a smaller font (Figures 2A to 2D). The
degree of repunching is inconsistent with respect to the
degree and direction of offset of the (smaller or underlying)
elements, and an argument could be made that some letters
were punched over more than once. For this reason, I
conclude that a  large over small legend  would be proper
nomenclature for this particular variety.

I had picked up this coin from a coin show
back in 2012. But, like many coins I have
purchased before it, it was put in a
Mylar flip, stored in a coin box, and
soon forgotten. In November of
2014, sharp-eyed collector Benoit
Boulet, from Montreal s north
shore, noticed a doubled obverse
legend example and posted his
finding on Numicanada.com.
In his own words, he described
it as (in French):  comme s il y
avait une 2e l gende plus  troite
par-dessus une premi re plus
large  (NumiCanada.com, 2014).
His observation basically translates that
this coin has a second narrower legend,
punched over by a wider legend.
Over the past few years, I have presented
several large cent Edward VII varieties
in this column, and I think I am only
scratching the surface for varieties
in this series. This variety is easily
seen without magnification; while
it is a tougher one to find, this
variety could be picked out at all
grades. So grab your loupe and
keep up the hunt!
Acknowledgements

Although I had cherry-
picked this coin back in 2012,
this variety was first published
and documented November of
2014 on Numicanada.com.
In my professional world of science,
it is not necessarily those who
make new discoveries that gain
accreditation; that goes to those who
first publish their results. Therefore discovery of this very
interesting variety is accredited to Benoit Boulet.

The beautiful MS-63 Red-Brown example shown here
was practically given away to my friend and budding large
cent collector D. Barker on the condition that he would
provide me with the fantastic photos you see here. Those
who have mastered the art of coin photography, and
microphotographs in particular, humble me.

Bank of Canada unveils new $10 banknote for Canada 150 celebrations
The banknote features 4 portraits of Canadian politicians, Inuit art and Canadian landscapes

n April 7, 2017, Bank
of Canada Governor
Stephen S. Poloz,

and Ginette Petitpas Taylor,
parliamentary secretary to the
minister of finance, unveiled
a new commemorative $10
banknote to celebrate the 150th
anniversary of Confederation.
On June 1, 40 million notes
will be release into circulation
to be readily available by
Canada Day.

It is just the fourth time
in Canada s history that a
commemorative banknote
has been produced. The
first was a special $25 note,
issued in 1935, to mark the
25th anniversary of the
accession of King George
V. Then in 1967, a $1
note was issued to mark
Canada s centennial
year. In 2015, the Bank
of Canada released a
commemorative $20
note in celebration of
Queen Elizabeth II as
the longest-reigning sovereigu 11 Lanaua s msw1y.

The new purple coloured 2017 polymer note  is intended
to captivate our imagination and instill pride in what we, as
a nation, have accomplished,  bank governor Stephen Poloz
said as he revealed that the note was three years in the making.

Tt celebrates the natural beauty and majesty of our land
and some of the important parliamentarians who helped shape
our great country.

The front of the bill shows four Canadian political figures
who helped shape the country: Sir John A. Macdonald,
Sir George-Etienne Cartier, Agnes Macphail and James
Gladstone. The note represents one of the few times a
Canadian woman and an indigenous Canadian have been
featured on the country s currency.

Macphail, a champion of equality and human rights, was
Canada s first female member of Parliament. First elected in
1921, she later went on to provincial politics, winning a seat
in the Ontario legislature in 1943.

In December, 2016, the
bank had announced plans to
put human rights activist Viola
Desmond s effigy on the $10
bill in 2018. This will make
Desmond the first Canadian
woman to grace a regularly
circulating bank note.

Gladstone, known by his
Blackfoot name Akay-na-muka,
was a member of the Kainai, or
Blood, First Nation who fought
for indigenous rights. In 1958,
he became the first person of a
treaty First Nation to be named
to the Senate.

The note for the country s
150th anniversary, to be
released before summer, is a
commemorative to supplement
the current design.

Its front also carries images of
Parliament s Hall of Honour, the
names of all the provinces and
territories and a depiction of the
Memorial Chamber Arch in the

Peace Tower.
The arch includes a colour-
shifting security feature designed to
prevent counterfeiting. There are also
maple leaves that appear to be 3D, but are flat to the touch.

On the back, a range of images capture the country s
diverse landscape, including the  Lions  or  Twin Sisters 
mountains overlooking Vancouver, a Prairie wheat field, the
Canadian Shield in Central Canada, Cape Bonavista on the
East Coast and the Northern Lights.

The design also incorporates Inuit and Metis cultural
elements, including a holographic reproduction of the
 Owl s Bouquet  stencil print created by Inuit artist
Kenojuak Ashevak, who lived in Nunavut the last
territory to join Confederation, in 1999. An arrow sash

Poloz said the reverse of the bill was designed based on
feedback from over 5,000 Canadians on what they wanted to
see on the bill.

All of those historical elements in the note s design show
why this year calls for a big celebration,  said Poloz.

ERROR OF_THE.MONTH  BY HENRY NIENHUIS FRCNA,FCNRA,FONA, LM #430

Clash of a different kind!
O ne of the most intriguing examples of minting errors comes from failure

of the press mechanism to feed a planchet before dies strike, causing
a die clash. If a planchet is not fed between the dies as they come
together the two dies can strike each other at full force. This may result in
them being damaged; imparting an outline of a portion of one s design
elements on the other. Even though coin presses were, in the last century,
designed to limit the damage that can result when this happens there are
still many examples of this occurring  even today.

Dies are negative images of the surface of the coin, thus the highest
points on the surface of the die actually produce the lowest points on the
surface of the coin (the fields). When the two dies come into contact, with
striking force, it is actually the lowest portions of the design elements that
interfere with each other. If this accident is left unnoticed by the press operator,
coins struck with these damaged dies will exhibit clashed die effects. This error,
in Canada, is primarily seen in all denominations of Queen Victoria circulating
coins; these pre-date the advances in coin press design.

Clashed die errors are characterized by the presence of raised areas which
are not part of the intended design elements. These raised areas, or clash
marks, are located in the lowest points on a coin s surface, typically the
fields of the coin. They are actually the portions of the field, 1.e., spaces
between the design elements present on the other side of the coin.

Often you will find coins exhibiting clash marks are given colourful
colloquial names such as: spikes in neck, bean in ear, hearing aid, half-moon,
etc. This happens because it is not immediately intuitive to the casual observer
what the raised areas represent. It is somewhat difficult to imagine what the
space between the design elements will look like.

Our error this month, a 1975 1-dollar nickel coin, is a much
harder to find example of a die clash called a collar clash.

This occurs when a hammer die hits hard with the collar and
the collar leaves an impression on the die. It can
happen when the hammer die is not properly aligned
in the press during the initial setup or becomes loose
during operation.

The reverse of this 1975 dollar
is an excellent example with the
clash marks, formed by the reeded-
edge pattern, on the rim of the coin,
extending from approximately 11:00
to 2:00. The coin s diagonally opposite
edge supports this diagnosis because
its rim is very thin compared with the
thicker portion containing the clash.

This indicates that the coin was struck
when the die was mis-aligned.

I thank Roger Paulen, the owner of
this coin, for bringing my attention to
it and for providing the images.
Keep your eyes open!

2017 Fine Silver 3-Coin Set; Royal Canadian
Mint Coin Lore: The Forgotten 1927 Designs

All three coins feature the unused circulation coin
designs intended to commemorate Canada s
Diamond Jubilee in 1927. Working with
the original sketches (and little else), the
Royal Canadian Mint s engravers set
out to interpret each artist s vision as
though the art had been entrusted to
them today, to mark Confederation s
150th anniversary.

The 90-year-old concepts have
been painstakingly adapted for modern
engraving techniques including a
reverse proof finish that allows the more
brilliant engraved elements to shine bright
against the matte backdrop. The one-cent coin
features an Art Nouveau-inspired design
by Canadian artist Gustav Hahn (1866-
1962), with a bough of maple leaves
encircling the commemorative dates
 1867-2017.  The five-cent coin by
Canadian artist J.E.H. MacDonald
(1873-1932) features a crowned
lion, as it stands perched on a
rock, gripping a maple leaf, which
represents the changing Canadian
landscape cradled by the sea; beneath
the forepaw is Canada s motto,  A MARI
USQUE AD MARE?  ( From Sea to Sea ),
while the commemorative dates, now added,
 1867  and  2017  are inscribed above the
lion. A second design by MacDonald
graces the reverse of the 25-cent coin,
and centres on a soaring view of the
iconic Peace Tower on Parliament
Hill. The clock tower soars high
above the clouds and is surrounded
by a ribbon-wrapped laurel of leaves,
from which hangs four bells an
ode to the Dominion Carillon, which
was inaugurated on July 1,
1927, during the Diamond
Jubilee festivities.
Each bell bears
engraved numbers that
combine to form the
commemorative dates
 2017  and  1867.

2017 $1 Fine Silver 2-Coin Set;
30th Anniversary Of The Loonie

The first coin features the design by Canadian
artist Robert-Ralph Carmichael that has
become synonymous with Canada s
currency: the iconic side-profile portrait
of a common loon on a still lake, where
it floats past the Group of Seven-esque
trees rising up on a small island behind it.
The entire scene is representative of the
lakes that dot the Canadian Shield, part of

the nation, and includes the engraved words
 CANADA  and  DOLLAR,  along with the
commemorative dates  1987-2017  to mark the
30th anniversary of Canada s $1 circulation coin.
The second coin represents the one-dollar
circulation coin that never was. Much as it
appeared on Canada s silver dollar between
1935 and 1986, the  Voyageur  design

by the artist Emanuel Hahn is a nod to
Canada s early history and the fur trade
era. A canoe moves swiftly past the wind-
swept pines that dot a semi-circular island.

An Aboriginal paddles at the bow, while the
voyageur paddles at the stern; between them
lies a bundle of wrapped furs; the stylized vertical
rays above represent the Aurora borealis. The reverse
also features the engraved words  CANADA  and
 DOLLAR,  along with the commemorative dates
 1987-2017.  Both coins have the effigy of Her
Majesty Queen Elizabeth II by Susanna Blunt on
the obverse.

2017 $30 Fine Silver Coin Zentangle  Art:
The Great Grey Wolf

The reverse design by Canadian artist Jori Van Der
Linde features a unique side-profile view of a
revered icon of the Canadian wilderness: the
great grey wolf (Canis lupus). Its familiar
silhouette, distinctive features and steely
gaze provide a framework for a life-
like portrait. The texture of the wolf s
fur lends itself beautifully to a layering
of repetitive abstract patterns, which
adds a stunning complexity to this fresh
artistic take on a traditional wildlife
portrait. Precision engraving and
multiple finishes ensure that
each pattern is kept distinct
from the other, with shaded
elements and thicker lines to
provide contrast and depth to
the overall arrangement.

2017 Ontario Numismatic Association
Convention

In late April, the annual Ontario Numismatic
Association Convention was held in Kitchener,
Ontario. The organization is celebrating its 55th year
of establishment and noted that over two dozen of
its member clubs have been organized for over fifty
years. The ONA also noted the increasing challenge of
reaching and gaining the support of today s younger
and more sophisticated collectors. The bourse was busy
with over sixty tables, quality collector exhibits were
displayed, educational programs held, and all this was
capped by the awards banquet. At the banquet several
major awards were granted to members for service to
the hobby in Ontario.
The ONA Award of Merit
was presented to Judy Blackman
as the Ontario resident who
has made the greatest personal
contributions to numismatics
at the local, provincial, and
national levels. Although she
has been active in organized
numismatics for only a
dozen years, she has been a
powerhouse volunteer in her
two local clubs, and she also edits several numismatic
newsletters.
The recently established
Bruce H. Razmann Award was
won by Henry Nienhuis for
exemplary executive service
to the ONA. In addition to
developing the ONA Web site,
he served as its Area 7 Director,
and he continues to provide
editorial support for the Ontario
Numismatist. As well, Henry
is an officer in two local clubs
and is RCNA President, and an
officer in several national numismatic organizations.
Fellow of the ONA Awards were granted three
members for their contributions and dedication to
numismatics in their local areas. Award recipients this
year were Frank Baka; Bill English, an ONA founding
member; and Monina McCullough-Regitko.
The Best of Show and People s Choice award went
to Brett Irick, FONA, for an exhibit titled  Personal
Artifacts of John Honeyford Campbell, First Master

  2017 RCNA Convention Sale

TCNC, Official RCNA Auctioneers for the 2017 Boucherville, QC venue, are thrilled to offer the public a
superb and diverse selection of numismatic material. This year s sessions are highlighted by The Bennett
Collection Part II consisting of an almost complete Bank of Canada set 1935 to present day mainly in
Uncirculated to Gem Uncirculated condition with a few issues in the VF to AU range. The notes being
offered in this sale is a continuation of the collection offered at the June Torex Sale. The sheer volume of
this collection required a two part sale; we are happy to offer the public the balance of this outstanding and
substantial assortment of Banknotes!
The sale also features a couple rather intriguing and possibly unique Collections/Accumulations:

First   The Sundstom Collection which consists of a fantastic assortment of Medals & Medalets from the
Temperance Movement period, A social and political campaign held in the 19th and through to the early
20th century, which includes an assortment of close to 200 examples.

Second   The Farley Vignette Collection. A collection of over 300 mainly BABN Vignettes. These are
an important and significant part of North American history. Since the middle of the 18th century all
documents of security such as banknotes, share certificates, passports, postage stamps and identification
documents have all benefitted from the use of hand-engraved images or vignettes printed on fine quality
papers by intaglio printing presses and using specialty inks. This assortment includes very few duplicates
and outlines the impressive artwork and labour intensive effort put into the ensuring a high quality product.

Another great highlight of the RCNA
Auction sale is a 1921 50 cents, PCGS graded
Specimen-64! It should bring a lot of attention.

NUMISMATIC LITERATURE
By ALAN ROY
The Henry Jackman Medal Collection

Henry Rutherford Jackman was born in 1900 to
H Henry B. Jackman and Sarah Ann Rutherford. He
married Mary Coyne Rowell in 1930, and they
had four children: Henry (Hal), Eric, Edward, and Nancy

During the years of the Depression, he built a successful
financial service company called Empire Life. Buoyed by
his business success, Jackman ran for federal office in
1940 and served as Member of Parliament representing
the Toronto riding of Rosedale, until 1949.

He spent the next few years pursuing philanthropic
projects, such as restoring the Rowell Room at the
University of Toronto s law library and bringing statues of
Winston Churchill and King Edward VII to Toronto

When Henry Jackman passed away in 1979, his
wife donated his medallic collection to the Medal
Collection of the Public Archives of Canada.
Most such donations are from public figures
such as Prime Ministers or Governors General
Their medals are typically awards for service or
other commemorative pieces acquired during
their careers. Jackman s collection was different.
Although he was a Member of Parliament, and
was gifted many medals during his career, he also
added pieces collected for pleasure He was in fact
a numismatist.

Because his collection was privately assembled,
it represented a broader and more diverse
assemblage of medals than are typically donated
to the Archives. Due to this, seventy were selected
to be displayed in a special exhibit. The official
catalogue was titled The Henry Jackman Medal
Collection.

The medals that seemed to attract Jackman were
large, artistic pieces. He was a fan of works by Dora
de P dery-Hunt. Eight examples of her work were
featured in the display, including medals bearing
the likenesses of Jackman himself (see catalogue s
cover) and of his wife. He was also a subscriber
to the American Society of Medalists, and a pair
of these medals was included. The catalogue has
26 pages, illustrates 12 medals and is with two
matching sections: English and French.

His collection covered many topics including
Canadian history, Winston Churchill (Jackman s
hero) and other statesmen, and artistic medals.

Of course, a wide array of Jackman s own awards is
included in the display. He was an Officer of the Order
of Canada, and his badge was included. On a more local
level, Jackman s City of Toronto Award of Merit was also
on show.

Most numismatists dream that their collections will
continue to exist after their deaths. Sadly, this is not
usually the case. Typically, a collection is broken up and
sold. It is heartening to know that, at least occasionally, a
collection can outlast the collector.

NOTES ON THE ANCIENT ANCESTORS OF MODERN COINS
NUMMUS_ MATRIX
BY JAMES R. BAKES
86. Striking Coins at the Mint of Rome, (redux)
About a decade ago I wrote an article in this space

entitled Striking Coins at the Mint of
Rome  (Nummus Matrix 5, CNJ Vol.
53 #1, January/February 2008). This was a
part of that year s general celebration of the
first coins struck at the mint in Ottawa in
1908. The coin I was writing about was a
denarius struck in ancient Rome in 46 BC,
by a moneyer named Titus Carisius, showing
on its reverse the coining implements of those
far off times. Now a new example has come to
my attention, one which may show something in
addition.

In ancient Rome all coinage was struck by
hand (i.e., hammered) at a mint located at or
perhaps inside the Temple of Juno Moneta.
Her temple stood on the Capitoline Hill
overlooking the Forum Romanum. At the
other end of this hill stood Rome s main
temple to Juno s consort Capitoline Jupiter.
Juno Moneta had as her sacred animal the
goose. It was the loud honking of the geese of
Juno that awakened the city to an attack by the Gauls

in 390 BC, so not only do we derive our words related to
money (monetary, money etc.) from her name but also the
word  monitor.  The mint located at this site supplied all
the coinage for Rome and the local area (Latium), but as
Rome s power grew and expanded into empire, the mint
grew too and by the first century BC the organisation of
the mint had made moneyer the first rung on the so-called
cursus honorum, the step-ladder of positions in the Roman
government that led all the way to consul, chief magistrate
of the Roman government.

The situation in Rome of 46 BC was a tumultuous one.
Two factions struggled for control of the government: those
conservatives who wanted to keep the old ways and whose
battle cry was Leibertas (Liberty) were led by Brutus (and
his supporters like Cassius), and those who wanted change,
and while  king  was a bad word in Rome historically,
foresaw a strong man leading the government as the road to
peace and prosperity. The faction was led by Julius Caesar
who had just come back from a successful war in Gallia
(Gaul, now essentially France).

The moneyers in Rome kept their positions for a year
during which they were free to choose the topics and
themes for their coinage. Many had traditionally
chosen heroic deeds performed in Rome s
service by one of their ancestors. Brutus
had been moneyer ten years previously, for
example and had chosen as one of his coin
themes an ancestor who had rid Rome of

kings centuries before.
When Titus Carisius took over the mint in
46 BC, it would appear that he wanted to wait
for the dust to settle and not choose sides in this
struggle for power. Eventually this led to civil war
which would not play out until nearly twenty
years later when Octavian became the first
emperor of Rome as Augustus. Bloody strife
lay ahead and it would seem Carisius wanted
none of it.

So, in the middle of this crisis he chose
as his theme  How we make our coins.  On
the obverse is a head of the cult statue of Juno
Moneta, likely copied from the one on site. Behind
her in the left field is MONETA. The reverse under
Carisius s name and enclosed in a laurel wreath shows
the coming implements: from the left, tongs to handle the
(presumably) hot blanks, the punch (reverse) die encircled
mysteriously by a laurel wreath, the anvil wherein was set
the obverse die and to the far right the hammer used to
strike each coin for an economy that had no paper money,
cheques or credit cards. It will be seen that these objects
are not shown to any kind of scale. The hammer seems
to just represent the idea of  hammer,  being relatively
small. What makes this piece unique is the tiny dot visible
where the coin blank should be. Is it the coin? Viewed in a
microscope the dot is integral, not a later addition or a bit
of accretion to the coin s surface. It appears to have been an
original part of the die. Did someone decide that this very
literal design needed further embellishment? We will likely
never know.

James R. Bakes is past editor of the Classical and Medieval Numismatic
Society Journal www.cmns.ca
